perturbation.changed_text:
Western Copper covenants and agrees with Glamis that, for a period of 6 months
after the Effective Date, it will not, directly or indirectly, either individually or in partnership or 
jointly or in conjunction with any Person, which will include being a principal, agent, 
shareholder, or advisor of such Person or in any other manner whatsoever,
(a) 
cairy on or be engaged in Mining Activities, or
i 162967.3
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a non-competition period of 2 years. Reducing this period to 6 months could be deemed unreasonably short and unenforceable under British Columbia law, especially given the nature of the agreement and the potential for significant harm to Glamis's business interests if Western Copper quickly re-enters the market. Courts in British Columbia consider the reasonableness of non-competition clauses, and a very short duration may be viewed as insufficient to protect legitimate business interests.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract law principles regarding the reasonableness of non-competition clauses in British Columbia.

perturbation.original_text:
For a period of 
30 days from the time of delivery of the Disposition Notice Glamis will, if requested by Western 
Silver, entertain an offer from Western Copper to acquire the Designated Mineral Property. In 
the ease of a Designated Mineral Property that Glamis intends to dispose of for cash 
consideration, the parties will negotiate in good faith to reach a mutually agreeable agreement for 
the sale to Western Copper of the [Designated Mineral Property. If Glamis and Western Copper 
are unable to negotiate an acceptable agreement with respect to the Designated Mineral Property 
within the 30 day period, Glamis may thereafter dispose of the Designated Mineral Property as it 
sees til in its absolute discretion. If Glamis does not dispose of the Designated Mineral Property 
within a period of 3 months from the first to occur of the date that Glamis and Western Copper 
acknowledge failure to negotiate an acceptable agreement with respect to the Designated Mineral 
Property and the end of the 30 day period, the provisions of this section 2.2 will once again apply 
to any intended disposition of the Designated Mineral Property by Glamis.
perturbation.changed_text:
For a period of 
5 days from the time of delivery of the Disposition Notice Glamis will, if requested by Western 
Silver, entertain an offer from Western Copper to acquire the Designated Mineral Property. In 
the ease of a Designated Mineral Property that Glamis intends to dispose of for cash 
consideration, the parties will negotiate in good faith to reach a mutually agreeable agreement for 
the sale to Western Copper of the [Designated Mineral Property. If Glamis and Western Copper 
are unable to negotiate an acceptable agreement with respect to the Designated Mineral Property 
within the 5 day period, Glamis may thereafter dispose of the Designated Mineral Property as it 
sees til in its absolute discretion. If Glamis does not dispose of the Designated Mineral Property 
within a period of 1 month from the first to occur of the date that Glamis and Western Copper 
acknowledge failure to negotiate an acceptable agreement with respect to the Designated Mineral 
Property and the end of the 5 day period, the provisions of this section 2.2 will once again apply 
to any intended disposition of the Designated Mineral Property by Glamis.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the negotiation period from 30 days to 5 days and the disposition period from 3 months to 1 month could be considered commercially unreasonable and a breach of the implied duty of good faith in contract law under British Columbia Law. The duty of good faith requires parties to act honestly and reasonably in performing their contractual obligations. A 5-day negotiation period may be insufficient for a complex transaction involving mineral properties, potentially hindering Western Copper's ability to conduct due diligence and secure financing, thereby undermining the purpose of the right of first offer.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied duty of good faith in contract law under British Columbia Law.
